answer: Yes.
question: Can you hear me?

answer: Yes.
question: But both of you, tell me first, are you OK?

answer: The flight was a little rocky from the start but nobody thought really anything of it.
question: Did you have any warning that something was wrong with the plane?

answer: No.
question: So no announcement from the cockpit that you remember, Frank?

answer: Yes, but, you know, it kind of struck us as a little odd, because they did also say to check your neighbor's seatbelts as well.
question: Dominique, do you remember any announcement other than to check your seatbelts?

answer: Well, it was incredibly shocking.
question: What does it feel like in the plane, Dominique?

answer: Well, none of the masks dropped, but, you know, we were -- it was very -- yes, I mean, we were very shaken.
question: What happened?

answer: I mean, it felt like forever to be honest with you because it does seemed like we were traveling so fast.
question: How long do you think it took you, Dominique, to stop?

answer: We were probably seven or eight rows down, just in front of the wing.
question: Dominique, where were you?

answer: I didn't see anybody injured.
question: Did you see people injured there?

answer: Well, you know, immediately people were trying to jump out of their seatbelts and get off.
question: When they finally gave you word, what did they say and what happened?

answer: I looked outside and like I see that the emergency vehicles were surrounding the plane and they were, you know, hosing it down, and then at that point people really started kind of getting irritated and asking, you know, for the --
question: And then, Frank, you wound up going off a slide, right?

answer: Yes.
question: Frank, are you still there?

answer: Yes.
question: How did you get off the plane?

answer: Yes, yes.
question: But do all your loved ones know that you're OK, Frank and Dominique?

answer: Yes.
question: The combination of more media access and this particular royal couple wanting to do it their own way?

answer: No, all I think it does is show the queen that her 61 years of service and duty have been worth every second.
question: So that fact, Victoria, do you think that changes the equation here and maybe opens a possibility for somewhat of a sunset?

answer: Absolutely.
question: Do you think there's a recognition, though, of how much energy William, especially with his marriage to Kate and now this little boy whatever his name will be, has given to the resurgence of popularity of the monarchy that might figure into who they want up front?

answer: You know, I think everybody in the back of their minds always thinks about that.
question: But is there a feel there in this event of Diana's presence, her significance with Williams?

question: What do you think this will mean going-forward in terms of how much focus will be on this new family?

question: What do you think that will mean in terms of the decisions he and his wife will make and how they raise their little boy?

answer: Yes, I think it's exactly right.
question: This could very well be a different lifestyle because of that early influence, is that what you're saying?

question: Not so much because of the succession, but that media spotlight may free him up a little bit?

question: But give me your take, what's the name going to be?

question: Nothing?

answer: Yes, there is, Chris.
question: Is there a little bit of that in you?

answer: That's right.
question: So that would have been -- will (ph) exciting about this little girl, yes?

answer: Chris, I -- I know his father well.
question: How do you think he will choose to raise his little boy?

answer: Since William and Kate got married, we've seen William be incredibly protective of Kate.
question: Do you think this will be a kid that will be thrust out there as look at the new royal or more of an accommodation of private and public?

answer: I don't know, they're getting him out of the car right now.

answer: Yes, very strange.
question: And this in the same area where everything else happened, true?

answer: We had conversations over the last few days.
question: Is that true?

question: Do -- do you believe he is safe there in Sanford?

answer: Yes, there have been.
question: I mean, you -- you have said, and we've heard through the family that there have been meaningful threats against his safety, yes?

answer: Well, you know, if you look at just the sound bite, I think it was -- it was inappropriate to suggest to suggest that 35 years ago, he could have -- Trayvon could have been him or whatever.
question: President Obama in his comments -- what have you thought about all this?

answer: The reality is, is that what George did was not just legally correct, but was appropriate for the situation that he was in.
question: And you acknowledge that but you have an explanation, which is?

answer: Well, again, this is not a stand-your-ground case, never was.
question: But do you think that this case is a legitimate starting- off point for discussions about concealed weapon laws and stand-your- ground?

answer: Well, hopefully, the family is getting some rest tonight, their first night -- night with a new baby of course.
question: What are our big moments tomorrow?

answer: Name -- who knows.
question: What about the name?

answer: That's right, of course.
question: You're really a priest and an expert, though, aren't you?

answer: Yes, I did.
question: And you saw what happened out there today, right?

answer: Well, first of all, he is not in charge of his security.
question: But should he be in charge of security when it only takes one bad person?
